This is an excellent and exciting new project. I understand the plan to create a new website for DCE at `aiascent.dev`, repurposing existing assets to build a homepage and an interactive whitepaper. My course of action is to answer your technical hosting questions, provide the initial planning and documentation artifacts to "pre-boot" this new website project, and give you a clear list of which existing DCE artifacts you should copy over for context. I will begin by creating a new artifact that provides a comprehensive plan for hosting both `aiascent.game` and `aiascent.dev` on your single server using Caddy, which is the best-practice solution for your setup. Then, I will generate the initial set of planning documents for the new website project itself, including a project vision, technical plan, and a specific plan for the interactive whitepaper. Finally, I will provide a clear, actionable list of the existing DCE artifacts you should port over. 1. **Answer Hosting Questions:** I will create a new artifact, **`A113. aiascent.dev - Multi-Domain Hosting Plan.md`**, to provide a definitive answer to your questions. It will explain that you can point both domains' DNS records to your single IP and use a reverse proxy like Caddy to route traffic based on the domain name requested. I will provide a sample `Caddyfile` configuration. 2. **Pre-boot `aiascent-dev` Project:** I will generate the initial set of documentation artifacts required to start the new website project using the DCE workflow. * Create **`A114. aiascent.dev - Project Vision and Goals.md`** to define the scope and purpose of the new website. * Create **`A115. aiascent.dev - Technical Scaffolding Plan.md`** to propose a technical stack (Next.js, React, TypeScript) suitable for building the homepage and interactive report viewer. * Create **`A116. aiascent.dev - Interactive Whitepaper Plan.md`** to detail the requirements and implementation strategy for adapting the report viewer from `aiascent.game`. * Create **`A117. aiascent.dev - Master Artifact List.md`** to serve as the `A0` file for this new project, cataloging all the newly created planning documents. 3. **Provide Porting Instructions:** I will include a `` section with a checklist of the essential documentation artifacts from the *current* DCE extension project that you should copy into your new `C:\Projects\aiascent-dev\context\dce` directory to provide context for that new development effort. # Artifact A113: aiascent.dev - Multi-Domain Hosting Plan # Date Created: C117 # Author: AI Model & Curator - **Key/Value for A0:** - **Description:** A technical guide explaining how to host multiple domains (aiascent.game and aiascent.dev) on a single server with one public IP address using a Caddy reverse proxy. - **Tags:** hosting, networking, dns, caddy, reverse proxy, multi-domain ## 1. Overview & Goal This document provides the technical solution for hosting both `aiascent.game` and the new `aiascent.dev` website on the same home server that is also running the vLLM instance. The goal is to configure the network and server to correctly route incoming traffic to the appropriate application based on the requested domain name. The recommended and most robust solution is to use a reverse proxy, and since you are already using Caddy, we will expand that configuration. ## 2. The Architecture The setup involves three main parts: DNS, Port Forwarding, and the Caddy Reverse Proxy. ``` +----------------+ +----------------+ +-----------------+ +---------------------+ | DNS Records | | AT&T Router | | Caddy Server |----->| aiascent.game (App) | | aiascent.game |----->| | | (Reverse Proxy) | | (localhost:3001) | | aiascent.dev | | (Public IP) |----->| | +---------------------+ +----------------+ | | | | | (Ports 80/443) | | | +---------------------+ +----------------+ +-----------------+----->| aiascent.dev (App) | | (localhost:3002) | +---------------------+ ``` ## 3. Step-by-Step Configuration ### Step 1: DNS Configuration You are correct in your thinking. You need to configure the DNS "A" records for both of your domains to point to the same public IP address provided by your AT&T router. - **`aiascent.game` -> A Record -> `[Your Public IP]`** - **`aiascent.dev` -> A Record -> `[Your Public IP]`** ### Step 2: Port Forwarding (AT&T Router) Your router is already configured to forward traffic for `aiascent.game`, but you should ensure it forwards all standard web traffic to your server's *local* IP address. - Forward incoming TCP traffic on port **80** to your server's local IP (e.g., `192.168.1.100`). - Forward incoming TCP traffic on port **443** to your server's local IP (e.g., `192.168.1.100`). Caddy will handle receiving traffic on these ports. ### Step 3: Caddy Reverse Proxy Configuration (Caddyfile) This is the core of the solution. Caddy will inspect the `Host` header of each incoming request and route it to the correct backend application running on a different internal port. This allows you to run multiple web services on the same machine. Below is a sample `Caddyfile` that handles both domains. You will run your `aiascent.game` server on port `3001` and your new `aiascent.dev` website server on a different port, like `3002`. ```caddy # Caddyfile for Multi-Domain Hosting { # Global options, like your email for Let's Encrypt SSL certificates email your-email@example.com } # Site 1: AI Ascent Game aiascent.game, www.aiascent.game { # Caddy automatically handles HTTPS for this domain. # Reverse proxy all requests for aiascent.game to your game server # running on localhost port 3001. reverse_proxy localhost:3001 } # Site 2: New DCE Website aiascent.dev, www.aiascent.dev { # Caddy automatically handles HTTPS for this domain as well. # Reverse proxy all requests for aiascent.dev to your new website server # running on localhost port 3002. reverse_proxy localhost:3002 } ``` ### How it Works: 1. A user requests `https://aiascent.dev`. 2. DNS resolves it to your public IP. 3. Your router forwards the request on port 443 to your server. 4. Caddy receives the request. It sees the request is for `aiascent.dev`. 5. It looks at the `aiascent.dev` block in the `Caddyfile` and proxies the request to the application running on `localhost:3002`. This setup is clean, secure (with automatic HTTPS), and easily scalable if you decide to add more domains in the future. # Artifact A114: aiascent.dev - Project Vision and Goals # Date Created: C117 # Author: AI Model & Curator - **Key/Value for A0:** - **Description:** High-level overview of the aiascent.dev website, its purpose as a promotional hub for DCE, and its development plan. - **Tags:** project vision, goals, scope, aiascent.dev, dce, website ## 1. Project Vision The vision for the `aiascent.dev` website is to create a professional, public-facing hub for the Data Curation Environment (DCE) project. It will serve as the primary destination for developers to learn about the DCE, understand its value proposition, and access resources like tutorials and the project's whitepaper. Crucially, the website itself will be a **living demonstration of the DCE's power**. It will be built from the ground up using the DCE workflow, serving as a tangible showcase of what can be achieved with this new paradigm of AI-assisted development. ## 2. High-Level Goals & Phases The project will be developed in distinct phases. ### Phase 1: Homepage & Core Content The goal of this phase is to establish the foundational website with a compelling homepage that introduces the DCE. - **Core Functionality:** - Develop a modern, responsive single-page homepage by adapting the shell of the `automationsaas` project. - Clearly articulate the problem DCE solves (the friction in AI context management) and its solution. - **Core Functionality:** - Add a "Tutorials" section, using the report viewer infrastructure to host interactive guides on "vibe coding" and using the DCE effectively. - Add a "Blog" or "Updates" section to communicate project progress. - **Outcome:** The `aiascent.dev` site becomes the central community and learning hub for the DCE project. # Artifact A115: aiascent.dev - Technical Scaffolding Plan # Date Created: C117 # Author: AI Model & Curator - ## 1. Project Vision

The vision of **aiascent.dev** is to create the official web presence for the Data Curation Environment (DCE) VS Code extension. It aims to provide a professional, informative website that will serve as the primary destination for users to learn about, download, and get support for the DCE. The site itself will be a testament to the power of the DCE, as it will be built using the very same artifact-driven, AI-assisted workflow it promotes.

## 2. High-Level Goals & Phases

The project will be developed in distinct phases to ensure an iterative and manageable workflow.

### Phase 1: Core Website and Interactive Whitepaper

The goal of this phase is to establish the foundational elements of the project, leveraging existing assets for rapid development.
-   **Core Functionality:**
    -   Develop a main homepage based on the `automationsaas` project shell, explaining the DCE's value proposition.
    -   Create an "Interactive Whitepaper" section by adapting the report viewer from `aiascent.game`.
    -   Host the "Process as Asset" whitepaper as the initial content for the viewer.
-   **Outcome:** A live, functional website at `aiascent.dev` that introduces the DCE to the world and showcases a key component built with the DCE methodology.

### Phase 2: Tutorial and "Vibe Coding" Hub

This phase will build upon the foundation of Phase 1 by adding educational content.
-   **Core Functionality:**
    -   Expand the report viewer to support multiple documents.
    -   Create and host a series of tutorials on how to "vibe code" and use the DCE effectively.
    -   Add a blog or articles section for development updates and thoughts on AI-assisted workflows.
-   **Outcome:** `aiascent.dev` becomes a central resource for learning the "AI Ascent" development methodology.

### Phase 3: Community and Integration

This phase focuses on building a community around the DCE and integrating with other platforms.
-   **Core Functionality:**
    -   Add links to the official VS Code Marketplace page.
    -   Integrate with GitHub for issue tracking and community contributions.
    -   Potentially add a forum or Discord integration for user support.
-   **Outcome:** A polished and comprehensive hub for the entire DCE project and its user community.

## 1. Overview

This document outlines the proposed technical scaffolding and file structure for **aiascent.dev**. This plan serves as a blueprint for the initial project setup, ensuring a clean, scalable, and maintainable architecture from the start, leveraging modern web development practices.

## 2. Technology Stack

-   **Language:** TypeScript
-   **Framework/Library:** React with Next.js (This is recommended for its performance, SEO benefits, and ease of routing, which will be useful for the different sections like the whitepaper).
-   **Styling:** SCSS or TailwindCSS (To be determined based on the styles of the imported `automationsaas` and `report viewer` components).
-   **Bundler:** Webpack (Handled automatically by Next.js).

## 3. Proposed File Structure

The project will adhere to a standard Next.js directory structure:

```
.
├── src/
│   ├── app/                # Next.js App Router for pages and layouts
│   │   ├── (main)/           # Main website routes
│   │   │   ├── page.tsx      # Homepage
│   │   │   └── layout.tsx
│   │   ├── whitepaper/       # Route group for the interactive whitepaper
│   │   │   ├── page.tsx
│   │   │   └── layout.tsx
│   │   └── global.scss     # Global styles
│   │
│   ├── components/         # Reusable React components (e.g., Navbar, Footer)
│   │   └── report-viewer/  # The adapted report viewer component
│   │
│   ├── lib/                # Utility functions, helpers
│   │
│   └── content/            # Static content, like the markdown/json for the whitepaper
│
├── public/                 # Static assets (images, fonts)
│
├── package.json            # Project manifest and dependencies
└── tsconfig.json           # TypeScript configuration
```

## 4. Key Architectural Concepts

-   **Separation of Concerns:** The structure separates pages, reusable UI components, and static content.
-   **Component-Based UI:** The UI will be built by composing small, reusable components. The core components from `automationsaas` (homepage layout) and `aiascent.game` (report viewer) will be adapted and placed in `src/components/`.
-   **Static Site Generation (SSG):** Next.js will be used to pre-render the homepage and whitepaper pages as static HTML, ensuring fast load times and good SEO.
-   **Strong Typing:** TypeScript will be used throughout the project to ensure type safety and improve developer experience.

## 1. Overview

This guide provides the necessary commands to turn your local project folder (`C:\Projects\aiascent-dev`) into a Git repository, link it to a new repository on GitHub, and outlines the sample workflow for using Git alongside the Data Curation Environment (DCE).

## 2. Prerequisites

*   You have `git` installed on your machine.
*   You have a GitHub account.

## 3. Step-by-Step Setup

### Step 1: Create a New Repository on GitHub

1.  Go to [github.com](https://github.com) and log in.
2.  In the top-right corner, click the `+` icon and select **"New repository"**.
3.  **Repository name:** Enter `aiascent-dev`.
4.  **Description:** (Optional) "Promotional website and interactive whitepaper for the Data Curation Environment (DCE) project."
5.  Choose **"Private"** or **"Public"**.
6.  **IMPORTANT:** Do **not** initialize the repository with a `README`, `.gitignore`, or `license`. We will be pushing our existing files, and this will prevent conflicts.
7.  Click **"Create repository"**.

GitHub will now show you a page with command-line instructions. We will use the section titled **"...or push an existing repository from the command line"**.

### Step 2: Initialize Git in Your Local Project

Open a terminal and navigate to your project's root directory (`C:\Projects\aiascent-dev`). Then, run the following commands one by one.

1.  **Initialize the repository:**
    ```bash
    git init
    ```

2.  **Add all existing files:**
    ```bash
    git add .
    ```

3.  **Create the first commit:**
    ```bash
    git commit -m "Initial commit: Pre-boot with planning artifacts from DCE C117"
    ```

## 4. Sample Development Workflow with DCE and Git

Git is a powerful tool for managing the iterative changes produced by the DCE. It allows you to quickly test an AI's proposed solution and revert it cleanly if it doesn't work, without losing your place.

### Step 1: Start with a Clean State
Before starting a new cycle, ensure your working directory is clean. You can check this with `git status`. All your previous changes should be committed.

### Step 2: Generate a Prompt and Get Responses
Use the DCE to generate a `prompt.md` file. Use this prompt to get multiple responses (e.g., 4 to 8) from your preferred AI model.

### Step 3: Paste and Parse
Paste the responses into the Parallel Co-Pilot Panel and click "Parse All".

1.  Review the responses and find one that looks promising.
2.  Select that response and use the **"Accept Selected Files"** button to write the AI's proposed changes to your workspace.
3.  Now, compile and test the application (`npm run dev`). Does it work? Does it have errors?

### Step 5: The "Restore" Loop
This is where Git becomes a powerful part of the workflow.

*   **If the changes are bad (e.g., introduce bugs, don't work as expected):**
    1.  Use the **"Restore Baseline"** button in the DCE, or run `git restore .` in the terminal.
    2.  This command instantly discards all uncommitted changes, reverting your files to the state of your last commit.
    3.  You are now back to a clean state and can go back to the Parallel Co-Pilot Panel, select a *different* AI response, and click "Accept Selected Files" again to test the next proposed solution.

*   **If the changes are good:**
    1.  Use the **"Baseline (Commit)"** button in the DCE, or use the Source Control panel in VS Code.
    2.  Write a commit message (e.g., "Feat: Implement homepage header via AI C5").
    3.  You are now ready to start the next development cycle from a new, clean state.

This iterative loop of `accept -> test -> restore` allows you to rapidly audition multiple AI-generated solutions without fear of corrupting your codebase.

This document serves as the blueprint for the main landing page (`/`) of the `aiascent.dev` website. ## 2. Page Goal

To captivate visiting developers by immediately showing them a powerful new tool (the DCE), explaining its benefits for AI-assisted development, and inspiring them with a vision of empowerment and heightened productivity.

## 3. Page Structure & Content Sections

### Section 1: Hero - "The 100x Workflow is Here"

*   **UI:** Full-screen, immersive. Uses the `ContainerScroll` animation.
*   **Visual:** The primary visual will be the **DCE in-action screenshot** (from A15. Asset Wishlist). This immediately shows, not just tells, what the product is.
*   **Headline:** "Automate Your AI Workflow. Become a 100x Citizen Architect."
*   **Sub-headline:** "The Data Curation Environment (DCE) is an open-source VS Code extension that transforms your interaction with LLMs from a conversation into a structured, scalable, and hyper-productive development process."
*   **Call to Action (CTA):** A prominent button: "Explore the Showcase" linking to `/showcase`. A secondary link: "View on GitHub".

### Section 2: The Problem - "Stop Chatting, Start Building"

*   **UI:** A clean, three-column layout.
*   **Headline:** "The Chaos of the 'Copy-Paste' Workflow"
*   **Content:** Briefly describe the pain points of current AI-assisted development:
    1.  **Context Blindness:** LLMs lack awareness of your full codebase.
    2.  **Manual Curation:** Manually assembling context in `files_list.txt` is tedious and error-prone.
    3.  **Single-Threaded Interaction:** Chat interfaces are linear, making it impossible to compare and test multiple solutions efficiently.
*   **Narrative:** Frame these issues as a "tax on your cognitive capital," slowing down the translation of vision into reality.

### Section 3: The Solution - "The DCE Advantage"

*   **UI:** A corresponding three-column layout that visually answers the problems in Section 2.
*   **Headline:** "A Structured Environment for Creation"
*   **Content:** Detail the core benefits of the DCE:
    1.  **Visual Context Curation:** "Use the File Tree View to visually select every file and folder the AI needs to know about. No more manual lists."
    2.  **Parallel Co-Piloting:** "Generate multiple AI responses and load them into a multi-tabbed panel. Diff, review, and test different solutions in seconds."
    3.  **The `git restore .` Loop:** "Instantly accept a promising solution to your workspace for testing. If it fails, a single command (`git restore .`) reverts everything, letting you test the next solution without fear."
*   **Narrative:** Position the DCE as the tool that liberates developers from tedious manual work, allowing them to focus on high-level architecture and creative problem-solving.

### Section 4: The Vision - "From Ghost Worker to Citizen Architect"

    *   Frame the DCE as the tool that enables this, turning "vibecoding" into a structured, architectural process.

import React, { useRef } from 'react'
import { useScroll, useTransform, motion } from 'framer-motion'

export const ContainerScroll = ({
  titleComponent,
}: {
  titleComponent: string | React.ReactNode
}) =\> {
  const containerRef = useRef\<any\>(null)
  const { scrollYProgress } = useScroll({
    target: containerRef,
  })
  const [isMobile, setIsMobile] = React.useState(false)

  React.useEffect(() =\> {
    const checkMobile = () =\> {
      setIsMobile(window.innerWidth \<= 768)
    }
    checkMobile()
    window.addEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
    return () =\> {
      window.removeEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
    }
  }, [])

  const scaleDimensions = () =\> {
    return isMobile ? [0.7, 0.9] : [1.05, 1]
  }

  const rotate = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], [20, 0])
  const scale = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], scaleDimensions())
  const translate = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], [0, -100])

  return (

      \<div

      \>

    \</div\>
  )
}

## 1. Purpose

This document provides a master system prompt to be used for generating all visual assets for the aiascent.dev website. Its goal is to establish a consistent, professional aesthetic that aligns with the project's identity as a sophisticated tool for developers. This prompt should be used as the foundational instruction set for generating the specific assets listed in A15.

## 2. The System Prompt

**Master System Prompt: The Citizen Architect's Toolkit**

You are an expert graphic designer and branding specialist. Your task is to generate a series of clean, professional, and thematically coherent visual assets for a developer-focused website promoting a VS Code extension called the "Data Curation Environment (DCE)".

**Your Core Directives:**

1.  **Adhere to the Master Aesthetic:** Your guiding aesthetic is **sophisticated, modern, and precise**. It should feel like a high-end developer tool.
    *   **Color Palette:** The primary theme is **dark mode**. Use a deep, near-black background (e.g., `#0A0A0A` or `hsl(0 0% 3.9%)`). Accents should be vibrant and futuristic, primarily using **electric blue, cyan, and a hint of deep purple**. White or light grey should be used for text and fine details to ensure high contrast and readability.
    *   **Style:** The style should be **clean and minimalist**. For icons, think simple, geometric shapes with clear meanings. For graphics, use sharp lines, subtle gradients, and a sense of depth without being overly complex. Avoid photorealism unless specifically requested.

2.  **Maintain Thematic Cohesion:** The assets must feel like they belong to a single, unified product suite. The core themes are:
    *   **Precision & Control:** The DCE allows developers to be precise. This can be visualized with grids, fine lines, and focused elements.
    *   **Workflow & Iteration:** The tool is about process. This can be visualized with circular motifs, arrows, and interconnected nodes.
    *   **AI Collaboration:** This is a human-AI partnership. This can be visualized by showing human and abstract digital elements interacting.

3.  **Technical Specifications:**
    *   **Icons (SVG):** Generate as SVG code. Icons should be monochrome or use a maximum of two colors from the palette. They must be clear and legible at small sizes. The style should be line-art or simple filled shapes.
    *   **Graphics (PNG/WEBP):** For more complex images like the OG:Image, the output should be a high-resolution PNG. The aspect ratio for the OG image must be 1200x630px.
    *   **Logo (SVG):** The logo must be exceptionally clean and symbolic. It needs to work as a single-color icon and with the full brand palette.

**Your Workflow:**

I will provide you with a specific request for an asset (e.g., "Generate the icon for 'Context Curation'"). You will apply these core directives to generate a single, high-quality asset that fits perfectly within the established brand identity.
</file_artifact>

- **Tags:** image generation, prompt engineering, system prompt, design, assets, aiascent-dev

## 1. Purpose

This document provides a master system prompt to be used for generating all visual assets (logos, icons, etc.) for the `aiascent.dev` website. Its goal is to establish a consistent, professional, and thematically aligned aesthetic that reflects the project's core identity as a sophisticated tool for AI-assisted development. This prompt is modeled on the successful `A179. RDS - Image Generation System Prompt.md`.

## 2. The System Prompt

**Master System Prompt: The Citizen Architect's Toolkit**

You are an expert graphic designer and visual identity consultant specializing in branding for high-end developer tools and enterprise software. Your task is to generate a series of clean, modern, and thematically rich assets for a project called **aiascent.dev**, the home of the "Data Curation Environment" (DCE) VS Code extension.

**Your Core Directives:**

1.  **Adhere to the Master Aesthetic:** Your guiding aesthetic is **"Precision Futurism."** This is a clean, dark-themed, and highly professional style. It is not dystopian cyberpunk or sterile sci-fi. It is the aesthetic of a powerful, well-crafted tool.
    *   **Color Palette:** Primarily dark, sophisticated backgrounds (deep charcoal, near-black). Accents should be vibrant and electric, conveying intelligence and energy. Primary accents are **electric blue (#00BFFF)** and **cyan (#00FFFF)**. Use these for glows, highlights, and key elements.
    *   **Style:** Vector-based, minimalist, and sharp. Lines should be clean. Gradients should be smooth and subtle. Avoid clutter and unnecessary detail. The feeling should be one of clarity, focus, and power.
    *   **Lighting:** For icons and logos, lighting should be internal, as if the elements themselves are emitting a soft, controlled glow. This reinforces the "intelligence" theme.

2.  **Embrace Thematic Reinforcement:** Every asset must visually communicate one of the core concepts of the DCE:
    *   **Curation & Precision:** Selecting and organizing complex information.
    *   **Parallelism & Comparison:** Viewing multiple options or streams of data simultaneously.
    *   **Iteration & Cycles:** A continuous, refining workflow.
    *   **Human-AI Collaboration:** A partnership between a human mind and a digital intelligence.

3.  **Maintain Professional Quality & Format:**
    *   **Format:** All assets should be generated as **SVG**s unless otherwise specified. They must have transparent backgrounds and be infinitely scalable.
    *   **Clarity:** Icons must be instantly recognizable and clear, even at small sizes. Logos must be legible and impactful.

**Your Workflow:**

I will provide you with a specific request for an asset (e.g., "an icon for Context Curation"). You will apply the **"Precision Futurism"** aesthetic and the **Thematic Reinforcement** principles to generate a single, high-quality SVG asset that fulfills the request.
</file_artifact>

You are a world-class graphic designer and branding expert specializing in developer tools and enterprise software. Your task is to generate a series of hyper-clean, professional, and thematically rich visual assets (logos, icons, and marketing images) for a project called **aiascent.dev**, a promotional website for a VS Code extension named the **Data Curation Environment (DCE)**.

2.  **Embrace Clarity and Recognizability:** Every icon and logo must be instantly recognizable and clearly communicate its purpose.
    *   **Simplicity is Key:** Icons should be simple enough to be understood at a small size (e.g., 16x16 pixels). Avoid excessive detail.
    *   **Metaphorical Consistency:** The visual metaphors should be consistent. If a "file" is represented in one icon, it should be represented similarly in others.

3.  **Technical Specifications:**
    *   **Format:** Generate assets as SVGs for scalability, unless a raster format like PNG is explicitly requested.
    *   **Background:** All logos and icons must be generated on a transparent background. Marketing images should adhere to the specified scene but maintain the core aesthetic.
    *   **Cleanliness:** Ensure vector assets have clean paths and no unnecessary anchor points.

**Your Workflow:**

I will provide you with a specific prompt for a single asset. You will apply the **Master Aesthetic** and all core directives to generate that asset. Pay close attention to the specific requirements of each prompt to create a cohesive and professional brand identity for aiascent.dev.

'use client'
import React, { useRef } from 'react'
import { useScroll, useTransform, motion } from 'framer-motion'
import Image from 'next/image'

export const ContainerScroll = ({
  titleComponent,
  children,
}: {
  titleComponent: string | React.ReactNode;
  children: React.ReactNode;
}) => {
  const containerRef = useRef<any>(null)
  const { scrollYProgress } = useScroll({
    target: containerRef,
  })
  const [isMobile, setIsMobile] = React.useState(false)

  React.useEffect(() => {
    const checkMobile = () => {
      setIsMobile(window.innerWidth <= 768)
    }
    checkMobile()
    window.addEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
    return () => {
      window.removeEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
    }
  }, [])

  const scaleDimensions = () => {
    return isMobile ? [0.7, 0.9] : [1.05, 1]
  }

  const rotate = useTransform(scrollYProgress,,)
  const scale = useTransform(scrollYProgress,, scaleDimensions())
  const translate = useTransform(scrollYProgress,, [0, -100])

  return (
    <div
      className="h-[60rem] md:h-[80rem] flex items-center justify-center relative p-2 md:p-20"
      ref={containerRef}
    >
      <div
        className="py-10 md:py-40 w-full relative"
        style={{
          perspective: '1000px',
        }}
      >
        <Header
          translate={translate}
          titleComponent={titleComponent}
        />
        <Card
          rotate={rotate}
          translate={translate}
          scale={scale}
        >
            {children}
        </Card>
      </div>
    </div>
  )
}

export const Header = ({ translate, titleComponent }: any) => {
  return (
    <motion.div
      style={{
        translateY: translate,
      }}
      className="div max-w-5xl mx-auto text-center"
    >
      {titleComponent}
    </motion.div>
  )
}

export const Card = ({
  rotate,
  scale,
  children,
}: {
  rotate: any
  scale: any
  translate: any
  children: React.ReactNode
}) => {
  return (
    <motion.div
      style={{
        rotateX: rotate, // rotate in X-axis
        scale,
        boxShadow:
          '0 0 #0000004d, 0 9px 20px #0000004a, 0 37px 37px #00000042, 0 84px 50px #00000026, 0 149px 60px #0000000a, 0 233px 65px #00000003',
      }}
      className="max-w-5xl -mt-12 mx-auto h-[30rem] md:h-[40rem] w-full border-4 border-[#6C6C6C] p-2 md:p-6 bg-[#222222] rounded-[30px] shadow-2xl"
    >
      <div className="bg-gray-100 h-full w-full rounded-2xl overflow-hidden">
        {children}
      </div>
    </motion.div>
  )
}

'use client'
import React, { useEffect, useState } from 'react'
import { motion, useAnimation } from 'framer-motion'
import { cn } from '@/lib/utils'

// NOTE: This is a simplified version of the Sparkles component from automationsaas for use in a Next.js App Router environment.
// It does not use the `tsparticles` library to avoid client-side dependency issues.

export const SparklesCore = ({
  className,
  particleColor = '#FFFFFF',
}: {
  className?: string
  background?: string
  minSize?: number
  maxSize?: number
  particleDensity?: number
  particleColor?: string
}) => {
  const [sparkles, setSparkles] = useState<any[]>([])
  const controls = useAnimation()

  useEffect(() => {
    const generateSparkles = () => {
      const newSparkles = Array.from({ length: 50 }).map(() => ({
        id: Math.random(),
        top: `${Math.random() * 100}%`,
        left: `${Math.random() * 100}%`,
        animationDelay: `${Math.random() * 2}s`,
      }))
      setSparkles(newSparkles)
    }

    generateSparkles()
    controls.start({
      opacity: 1,
      transition: {
        duration: 1,
      },
    })
  }, [controls])

  return (
    <div className={cn('relative w-full h-full', className)}>
      {sparkles.map((sparkle) => (
        <motion.div
          key={sparkle.id}
          className="absolute rounded-full"
          style={{
            top: sparkle.top,
            left: sparkle.left,
            width: `${Math.random() * 2 + 1}px`,
            height: `${Math.random() * 2 + 1}px`,
            backgroundColor: particleColor,
            animation: `pulse ${Math.random() * 3 + 2}s infinite alternate`,
            animationDelay: sparkle.animationDelay,
          }}
          animate={{
            opacity:,
          }}
          transition={{
            duration: Math.random() * 2 + 1,
            repeat: Infinity,
            delay: Math.random(),
          }}
        ></motion.div>
      ))}
      <style jsx>{`
        @keyframes pulse {
          0% {
            transform: scale(0.5);
            opacity: 0.5;
          }
          100% {
            transform: scale(1.2);
            opacity: 1;
          }
        }
      `}</style>
    </div>
  )
}

## 2. The System Prompt

**Master System Prompt: The Digital Architect's Toolkit**

You are an expert graphic designer and brand identity specialist with a deep understanding of iconography for developer tools and high-tech software. Your task is to generate a series of clean, modern, and thematically rich vector-style graphics for the `aiascent.dev` website, a promotional site for a powerful VS Code extension.

**Your Core Directives:**

1.  **Adhere to the Master Aesthetic:** Your guiding aesthetic is **"Sophisticated & Futuristic Minimalism."**
    *   **Style:** Clean lines, geometric shapes, and a minimalist approach are paramount. Avoid clutter, excessive detail, and photorealism. The output should be suitable for SVG format.
    *   **Color Palette:** The primary palette is monochrome (shades of dark gray, black, and white) accented with a vibrant, glowing **electric blue or cyan**. Gradients should be smooth and used purposefully to suggest energy or digital light.
    *   **Feeling:** The assets should feel precise, professional, innovative, and authoritative. They belong to a cutting-edge tool for serious developers.

2.  **Embrace Clarity and Recognizability:** Every icon and logo must have a dual purpose.
    *   **Purpose 1: Be Instantly Recognizable.** The design must be simple and clear enough to be understood at small sizes (e.g., as a favicon or in a feature list).
    *   **Purpose 2: Convey the Concept.** The visual metaphor must directly relate to the feature or idea it represents (e.g., "Context Curation" should visually suggest file management or selection).

3.  **Maintain Vector-Ready Quality:**
    *   **Format:** Generate images that look like clean vector graphics. Use solid colors, simple gradients, and sharp edges. Do not produce rasterized, painterly, or complex photographic styles. The final assets will be used as SVGs on the website.
    *   **Background:** Unless specified otherwise, generate all icons and logos on a transparent or solid dark background to fit the website's dark-mode-first theme.

**Your Workflow:**

## 2. The System Prompt

**Master System Prompt: The DCE Brand Lens**

You are an expert brand designer and visual identity specialist. Your task is to generate a series of logos, icons, and images for `aiascent.dev`, the promotional website for the **Data Curation Environment (DCE)**, a sophisticated VS Code extension for developers.

**Your Core Directives:**

    *   **Style:** Clean, vector-based graphics for icons and logos. For more complex images, aim for a hyper-realistic or photorealistic style that feels grounded and professional. Avoid cartoonish or overly abstract styles.
    *   **Mood:** The mood is authoritative, intelligent, and powerful. The visuals should convey precision, efficiency, and the transformative potential of the DCE tool.

2.  **Maintain Cohesion and Clarity:**
    *   **Icons:** Icons must be instantly recognizable and communicate a single concept clearly. They should be designed as a cohesive set, sharing the same line weight, color palette, and visual language. They should be delivered as SVGs on a transparent background.
    *   **Logos:** The logo should be simple, memorable, and scalable. It must work well in both monochrome and color, and on both light and dark backgrounds.
    *   **Imagery:** More complex images (like the OG image) should feel like professional product shots or well-composed digital art. They must adhere to the core color palette and mood.

3.  **Technical Specifications:**
    *   **Format:** Unless specified otherwise, generate assets in a format suitable for web use (SVG for vectors, PNG/WEBP for raster images).
    *   **Background:** All icons and logos must be generated on a transparent background.
    *   **Aspect Ratio:** Pay close attention to specified aspect ratios, especially for social media images (e.g., 1.91:1 for OG images).

**Your Workflow:**

I will provide you with specific, individual prompts for each asset required. For each prompt, you will apply this Master System Prompt to ensure the final output is stylistically and thematically aligned with the `aiascent.dev` brand identity.

## 1. Purpose

This document provides a master system prompt to be used for generating all visual assets for the `aiascent.dev` website. Its goal is to establish a consistent, professional, and thematically resonant aesthetic that reflects the sophistication and power of the Data Curation Environment (DCE).

## 2. The System Prompt

**Master System Prompt: The Citizen Architect's Toolkit**

You are an expert graphic designer and brand strategist specializing in developer tools and high-tech software. Your task is to generate a series of hyper-clean, professional, and thematically rich assets (logos, icons, and images) for a promotional website for a VS Code extension called the "Data Curation Environment" (DCE).

**Your Core Directives:**

1.  **Adhere to the Master Aesthetic:** Your guiding aesthetic is **"Sophisticated Developer Precision."** This is a dark-mode-first design language that is clean, minimalist, and authoritative.
    *   **Color Palette:** The primary background is a very dark gray or near-black (`#111827` or similar). The primary accent color is a vibrant, electric cyan/blue (`#22d3ee`). A secondary accent of a deep purple (`#8b5cf6`) can be used for contrast. Text and secondary elements are typically off-white or light gray.
    *   **Style:** Minimalist and geometric. Lines are clean and sharp. Avoid clutter, noise, and overly complex textures. The feeling should be one of precision, control, and power.
    *   **Lighting:** For images, lighting should be dramatic and cinematic, as if in a high-end tech commercial. Think soft ambient light with sharp, focused highlights on key elements. For icons and logos, lighting is generally flat and graphical, but subtle gradients can be used.

2.  **Fulfill the Asset's Purpose:** Every asset you create has a specific job.
    *   **Logos & Icons:** These must be instantly recognizable and symbolic. They should be simple enough to work at small sizes (like a favicon) but distinctive enough to be memorable. They must be generated as SVGs or high-resolution PNGs with transparent backgrounds.
    *   **Illustrations & Images:** These assets tell a story. They must not only depict the subject of the prompt but also reinforce the core themes of the DCE: precision, control, efficiency, and the power of human-AI collaboration.

3.  **Maintain Technical Excellence:**
    *   **Vector-First (for Logos/Icons):** When creating logos and icons, think in terms of vectors. The output should be clean enough to be easily traced into an SVG.
    *   **High Resolution:** All assets should be generated at a high resolution suitable for modern high-DPI displays.
    *   **Consistency:** All generated assets must look like they belong to the same brand family. Use the color palette and minimalist style consistently across all outputs.

**Your Workflow:**

I will provide you with a specific prompt for a single asset (e.g., "Create a logo," "Generate an icon for 'Context Curation'"). You will apply the **"Sophisticated Developer Precision"** aesthetic and the above directives to generate a single, high-quality asset that perfectly fits the `aiascent.dev` brand.
</file_artifact>

'use client'
import React, { useRef } from 'react'
import { useScroll, useTransform, motion } from 'framer-motion'
import Image from 'next/image'

export const ContainerScroll = ({
  titleComponent,
  children,
}: {
  titleComponent: string | React.ReactNode
  children: React.ReactNode
}) => {
  const containerRef = useRef<any>(null)
  const { scrollYProgress } = useScroll({
    target: containerRef,
  })
  const [isMobile, setIsMobile] = React.useState(false)

  React.useEffect(() => {
    const checkMobile = () => {
      setIsMobile(window.innerWidth <= 768)
    }
    checkMobile()
    window.addEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
    return () => {
      window.removeEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
    }
  }, [])

  const scaleDimensions = () => {
    return isMobile ? [0.7, 0.9] : [1.05, 1]
  }

  const rotate = useTransform(scrollYProgress,,)
  const scale = useTransform(scrollYProgress,, scaleDimensions())
  const translate = useTransform(scrollYProgress,, [0, -100])

  return (
    <div
      className="h-[60rem] md:h-[80rem] flex items-center justify-center relative p-2 md:p-20"
      ref={containerRef}
    >
      <div
        className="py-10 md:py-40 w-full relative"
        style={{
          perspective: '1000px',
        }}
      >
        <Header
          translate={translate}
          titleComponent={titleComponent}
        />
        <Card
          rotate={rotate}
          translate={translate}
          scale={scale}
        >
          {children}
        </Card>
      </div>
    </div>
  )
}

export const Header = ({ translate, titleComponent }: any) => {
  return (
    <motion.div
      style={{
        translateY: translate,
      }}
      className="div max-w-5xl mx-auto text-center"
    >
      {titleComponent}
    </motion.div>
  )
}

export const Card = ({
  rotate,
  scale,
  children,
}: {
  rotate: any
  scale: any
  translate: any
  children: React.ReactNode
}) => {
  return (
    <motion.div
      style={{
        rotateX: rotate, // rotate in X-axis

        boxShadow:
          '0 0 #0000004d, 0 9px 20px #0000004a, 0 37px 37px #00000042, 0 84px 50px #00000026, 0 149px 60px #0000000a, 0 233px 65px #00000003',
      }}
      className="max-w-5xl -mt-12 mx-auto h-[30rem] md:h-[40rem] w-full border-4 border-[#6C6C6C] p-2 md:p-6 bg-[#222222] rounded-[30px] shadow-2xl"
    >
      <div className="bg-gray-100 h-full w-full rounded-2xl overflow-hidden">
        {children}
      </div>
    </motion.div>
  )
}

## 1. Purpose

This document provides a master system prompt to be used for generating all visual assets for the `aiascent.dev` website. Its goal is to establish a consistent aesthetic and thematic direction for the image generation AI, ensuring that all logos, icons, and images contribute to the project's professional and sophisticated brand identity. This artifact is modeled on the successful `A179. RDS - Image Generation System Prompt.md` from the `aiascent.game` project.

## 2. The System Prompt

**Master System Prompt: The Digital Architect's Toolkit**

You are an expert graphic designer and branding specialist with a deep understanding of user interface design, iconography, and developer tool aesthetics. Your task is to generate a series of clean, professional, and thematically coherent visual assets for **aiascent.dev**, the promotional website for a VS Code extension called the **Data Curation Environment (DCE)**.

**Your Core Directives:**

1.  **Adhere to the Master Aesthetic:** Your guiding aesthetic is **"Sophisticated, Modern, and Precise."** This reflects the nature of a high-end developer tool.
    *   **Color Palette:** The primary theme is dark mode. Use a base of near-black or very dark charcoal (`#111827`). The primary accent color is a vibrant, electric blue or cyan (`#22d3ee`), used to convey intelligence, clarity, and energy. Secondary accents can include a cool-toned purple (`#8b5cf6`) or a clean white/light gray for text and highlights.
    *   **Style:** The style should be clean, minimalist, and often abstract or symbolic. For icons, think vector-based, flat, or subtly 2.5D designs. Avoid overly complex or realistic imagery unless specifically requested. The overall feeling should be professional, trustworthy, and futuristic.
    *   **Lighting & Effects:** Use subtle gradients, soft glows, and sharp lines to create a sense of digital precision and depth. Avoid anything that looks cartoonish or hand-drawn.

2.  **Embrace the Core Metaphor:** The DCE is a tool for **"Citizen Architects"**—developers who build complex systems with AI. Your visuals should evoke themes of:
    *   **Structure & Architecture:** Grids, blueprints, interconnected nodes, layers.
    *   **Clarity & Focus:** Magnifying glasses, lenses, highlighted text or code, clean interfaces.
    *   **Workflow & Iteration:** Circular arrows, branching paths, gears, process diagrams.
    *   **Human-AI Collaboration:** Abstract representations of a human mind and a digital network intertwining.

3.  **Prioritize Clarity and Scalability:**
    *   **Icons:** Must be instantly recognizable and legible at small sizes. They should be designed as SVGs with clean lines and a limited color palette. They must work on a dark background.
    *   **Logos:** Must be simple, memorable, and scalable. The design should encapsulate the core concept of the brand.
    *   **Images:** Should be high-resolution and composed with clear focal points.

**Your Workflow:**

I will provide you with a specific request for a visual asset (e.g., "an icon for 'Context Curation'"). You will apply the **Master Aesthetic** and the **Core Metaphor** to generate a single, high-quality asset that perfectly fits the `aiascent.dev` brand identity. You will focus on fulfilling the specific prompt while ensuring it aligns with the overall design system established here.

'use client'
import React, { useRef } from 'react'
import { useScroll, useTransform, motion } from 'framer-motion'

export const ContainerScroll = ({
  titleComponent,
  children,
}: {
  titleComponent: string | React.ReactNode;
  children: React.ReactNode;
}) => {
  const containerRef = useRef<any>(null)
  const { scrollYProgress } = useScroll({
    target: containerRef,
  })
  const [isMobile, setIsMobile] = React.useState(false)

  React.useEffect(() => {
    const checkMobile = () => {
      setIsMobile(window.innerWidth <= 768)
    }
    checkMobile()
    window.addEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
    return () => {
      window.removeEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
    }
  }, [])

  const scaleDimensions = () => {
    return isMobile ? [0.7, 0.9] : [1.05, 1]
  }

  const rotate = useTransform(scrollYProgress,,)
  const scale = useTransform(scrollYProgress,, scaleDimensions())
  const translate = useTransform(scrollYProgress,, [0, -100])

  return (
    <div
      className="h-[80rem] flex items-center justify-center relative p-2 md:p-20"
      ref={containerRef}
    >
      <div
        className="py-10 md:py-40 w-full relative"
        style={{
          perspective: '1000px',
        }}
      >
        <Header
          translate={translate}
          titleComponent={titleComponent}
        />
        <Card
          rotate={rotate}
          translate={translate}
          scale={scale}
        >
          {children}
        </Card>
      </div>
    </div>
  )
}

export const Header = ({ translate, titleComponent }: any) => {
  return (
    <motion.div
      style={{
        translateY: translate,
      }}
      className="div max-w-5xl mx-auto text-center"
    >
      {titleComponent}
    </motion.div>
  )
}

export const Card = ({
  rotate,
  scale,
  children,
}: {
  rotate: any
  scale: any
  translate: any
  children: React.ReactNode
}) => {
  return (
    <motion.div
      style={{
        rotateX: rotate, // rotate in X-axis

          '0 0 #0000004d, 0 9px 20px #0000004a, 0 37px 37px #00000042, 0 84px 50px #00000026, 0 149px 60px #0000000a, 0 233px 65px #00000003',

## 2\. The Master System Prompt

**Master System Prompt: The AIAscent Aesthetic**

You are an expert digital artist and UI/UX designer tasked with creating visual assets for **aiascent.dev**, the promotional website for a sophisticated developer tool called the Data Curation Environment (DCE).

**Your Core Directives:**

1.  **Adhere to the Master Aesthetic:** The aesthetic is **Modern, Professional, Futuristic, and Precise**. The website uses a dark-mode-first design philosophy.

      * **Color Palette:** Dominated by dark backgrounds (deep navy, charcoal, or black) with vibrant, futuristic accents. Primary accents should be electric blue, cyan, and deep purple. Use white or light gray for contrast and text.
      * **Style:** Clean, minimalist, and high-tech. Think of the interfaces seen in advanced engineering software or sophisticated visualization tools. Use sharp lines, subtle gradients, and occasional holographic or glowing effects to suggest advanced technology.
      * **Inspiration:** Draw inspiration from the clean lines of modern developer tools (like VS Code or Linear) combined with the optimistic, technologically advanced aspects of **Solarpunk** design (clean energy, integration, empowerment).

2.  **Asset Type Specific Guidelines:**

      * **Icons (SVG):**

          * Icons must be simple, recognizable, and scalable.
          * Use a consistent line weight.
          * They should primarily use the accent colors (blue, cyan, purple) against the dark background.
          * Avoid excessive detail; focus on clear communication of the concept.

      * **Logos & Wordmarks (SVG):**

          * The logo should be sleek and professional.
          * It must work well in both full color and monochrome (e.g., solid white).
          * The design should evoke themes of ascent, precision, data, or architecture.

      * **Illustrations/Images (PNG/WEBP):**

          * Images should be cinematic and visually rich, adhering to the color palette.
          * They should convey the power and impact of the DCE tool.
          * Use realistic lighting, even when depicting futuristic concepts.

3.  **Thematic Consistency:** Ensure all assets feel like they belong to the same ecosystem. The visuals should reinforce the core message of the DCE: empowering developers ("Citizen Architects") to master the human-AI workflow.

**Your Workflow:**

I will provide you with specific prompts for individual assets. For each prompt, you will apply this Master Aesthetic and the relevant Asset Type Specific Guidelines to generate the visual asset.

// Ported from AutomationSaaS (C3)
'use client'

import { cn } from '@/lib/utils'
import React, {
  createContext,
  useState,
  useContext,
  useRef,
  useEffect,
} from 'react'

const MouseEnterContext = createContext\<
  [boolean, React.Dispatch\<React.SetStateAction\<boolean\>\>] | undefined

> (undefined)

export const CardContainer = ({
  children,
  className,
  containerClassName,
}: {
  children?: React.ReactNode
  className?: string
  containerClassName?: string
}) =\> {
  const containerRef = useRef\<HTMLDivElement\>(null)
  const [isMouseEntered, setIsMouseEntered] = useState(false)

  const handleMouseMove = (e: React.MouseEvent\<HTMLDivElement\>) =\> {
    if (\!containerRef.current) return
    const { left, top, width, height } =
      containerRef.current.getBoundingClientRect()
    const x = (e.clientX - left - width / 2) / 25
    const y = (e.clientY - top - height / 2) / 25
    containerRef.current.style.transform = `rotateY(${x}deg) rotateX(${y}deg)`
  }

  const handleMouseEnter = (e: React.MouseEvent\<HTMLDivElement\>) =\> {
    setIsMouseEntered(true)
    if (\!containerRef.current) return
  }

  const handleMouseLeave = (e: React.MouseEvent\<HTMLDivElement\>) =\> {
    if (\!containerRef.current) return
    setIsMouseEntered(false)
    containerRef.current.style.transform = `rotateY(0deg) rotateX(0deg)`
  }
  return (
    \<MouseEnterContext.Provider value={[isMouseEntered, setIsMouseEntered]}\>
      \<div
        className={cn('flex items-center justify-center', containerClassName)}
        style={{
          perspective: '1000px',
        }}
      \>
        \<div
          ref={containerRef}
          onMouseEnter={handleMouseEnter}
          onMouseMove={handleMouseMove}
          onMouseLeave={handleMouseLeave}
          className={cn(
            'flex items-center justify-center relative transition-all duration-200 ease-linear',
            className
          )}
          style={{
            transformStyle: 'preserve-3d',
          }}
        \>
          {children}
        \</div\>
      \</div\>
    \</MouseEnterContext.Provider\>
  )
}

export const CardBody = ({
  children,
  className,
}: {
  children: React.ReactNode
  className?: string
}) =\> {
  return (
    \<div
      className={cn(
        'h-96 w-96 [transform-style:preserve-3d]  [&\>\*]:[transform-style:preserve-3d]',
        className
      )}
    \>
      {children}
    \</div\>
  )
}

export const CardItem = ({
  as: Tag = 'div',
  children,
  className,
  translateX = 0,
  translateY = 0,
  translateZ = 0,
  rotateX = 0,
  rotateY = 0,
  rotateZ = 0,
  ...rest
}: {
  as?: React.ElementType
  children: React.ReactNode
  className?: string
  translateX?: number | string
  translateY?: number | string
  translateZ?: number | string
  rotateX?: number | string
  rotateY?: number | string
  rotateZ?: number | string
[key: string]: any // Added to allow spread props
}) =\> {
  const ref = useRef\<HTMLDivElement\>(null)
  const [isMouseEntered] = useMouseEnter()

  useEffect(() =\> {
    handleAnimations()
  }, [isMouseEntered])

  const handleAnimations = () =\> {
    if (\!ref.current) return
    if (isMouseEntered) {
      ref.current.style.transform = `translateX(${translateX}px) translateY(${translateY}px) translateZ(${translateZ}px) rotateX(${rotateX}deg) rotateY(${rotateY}deg) rotateZ(${rotateZ}deg)`
    } else {
      ref.current.style.transform = `translateX(0px) translateY(0px) translateZ(0px) rotateX(0deg) rotateY(0deg) rotateZ(0deg)`
    }
  }

  return (
    \<Tag
      ref={ref}
      className={cn('w-fit transition duration-200 ease-linear', className)}
      {...rest}
    \>
      {children}
    \</Tag\>
  )
}

// Create a hook to use the context
export const useMouseEnter = () =\> {
  const context = useContext(MouseEnterContext)
  if (context === undefined) {
    throw new Error('useMouseEnter must be used within a MouseEnterProvider')
  }
  return context
}
\</file\_artifact\>

'use client'
import React, { useRef } from 'react'
import { useScroll, useTransform, motion, MotionValue } from 'framer-motion'
import Image from 'next/image'

export const ContainerScroll = ({
  titleComponent,
  children,
}: {
  titleComponent: string | React.ReactNode
  children: React.ReactNode
}) =\> {
  const containerRef = useRef\<any\>(null)
  const { scrollYProgress } = useScroll({
    target: containerRef,
  })
  const [isMobile, setIsMobile] = React.useState(false)

  React.useEffect(() =\> {
    const checkMobile = () =\> {
      setIsMobile(window.innerWidth \<= 768)
    }
    checkMobile()
    window.addEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
    return () =\> {
      window.removeEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
    }
  }, [])

  const scaleDimensions = () =\> {
    return isMobile ? [0.7, 0.9] : [1.05, 1]
  }

  const rotate = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], [20, 0])
  const scale = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], scaleDimensions())
  const translate = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], [0, -100])

  return (
    \<div
      className="h-[60rem] md:h-[80rem] flex items-center justify-center relative p-4 md:p-20"
      ref={containerRef}
    \>
      \<div
        className="py-10 md:py-40 w-full relative"
        style={{
          perspective: '1000px',
        }}
      \>
        \<Header

          titleComponent={titleComponent}

        \<Card

          translate={translate}

      \</div\>
    \</div\>

'use client'

import { cn } from '@/lib/utils'
import React, {
  createContext,
  useState,
  useContext,
  useRef,
  useEffect,
} from 'react'

const MouseEnterContext = createContext\<
  [boolean, React.Dispatch\<React.SetStateAction\<boolean\>\>] | undefined

> (undefined)

export const CardContainer = ({
  children,
  className,
  containerClassName,
}: {
  children?: React.ReactNode
  className?: string
  containerClassName?: string
}) =\> {
  const containerRef = useRef\<HTMLDivElement\>(null)
  const [isMouseEntered, setIsMouseEntered] = useState(false)

  const handleMouseMove = (e: React.MouseEvent\<HTMLDivElement\>) =\> {
    if (\!containerRef.current) return
    const { left, top, width, height } =
      containerRef.current.getBoundingClientRect()
    const x = (e.clientX - left - width / 2) / 25
    const y = (e.clientY - top - height / 2) / 25
    containerRef.current.style.transform = `rotateY(${x}deg) rotateX(${y}deg)`
  }

  const handleMouseEnter = (e: React.MouseEvent\<HTMLDivElement\>) =\> {
    setIsMouseEntered(true)
    if (\!containerRef.current) return
  }

  const handleMouseLeave = (e: React.MouseEvent\<HTMLDivElement\>) =\> {
    if (\!containerRef.current) return
    setIsMouseEntered(false)
    containerRef.current.style.transform = `rotateY(0deg) rotateX(0deg)`
  }
  return (
    \<MouseEnterContext.Provider value={[isMouseEntered, setIsMouseEntered]}\>
      \<div
        className={cn('flex items-center justify-center', containerClassName)}
        style={{
          perspective: '1000px',
        }}
      \>
        \<div
          ref={containerRef}
          onMouseEnter={handleMouseEnter}
          onMouseMove={handleMouseMove}
          onMouseLeave={handleMouseLeave}
          className={cn(
            'flex items-center justify-center relative transition-all duration-200 ease-linear',
            className
          )}
          style={{
            transformStyle: 'preserve-3d',
          }}
        \>
          {children}
        \</div\>
      \</div\>
    \</MouseEnterContext.Provider\>
  )
}

export const CardBody = ({
  children,
  className,
}: {
  children: React.ReactNode
  className?: string
}) =\> {
  return (
    \<div
      className={cn(
        'h-96 w-96 [transform-style:preserve-3d]  [&\>\*]:[transform-style:preserve-3d]',
        className
      )}
    \>
      {children}
    \</div\>
  )
}

export const CardItem = ({
  as: Tag = 'div',
  children,
  className,
  translateX = 0,
  translateY = 0,
  translateZ = 0,
  rotateX = 0,
  rotateY = 0,
  rotateZ = 0,
  ...rest
}: {
  as?: React.ElementType
  children: React.ReactNode
  className?: string
  translateX?: number | string
  translateY?: number | string
  translateZ?: number | string
  rotateX?: number | string
  rotateY?: number | string
  rotateZ?: number | string
}) =\> {
  const ref = useRef\<HTMLDivElement\>(null)
  const [isMouseEntered] = useMouseEnter()

  useEffect(() =\> {
    handleAnimations()
  }, [isMouseEntered])

  const handleAnimations = () =\> {
    if (\!ref.current) return
    if (isMouseEntered) {
      ref.current.style.transform = `translateX(${translateX}px) translateY(${translateY}px) translateZ(${translateZ}px) rotateX(${rotateX}deg) rotateY(${rotateY}deg) rotateZ(${rotateZ}deg)`
    } else {
      ref.current.style.transform = `translateX(0px) translateY(0px) translateZ(0px) rotateX(0deg) rotateY(0deg) rotateZ(0deg)`
    }
  }

  return (
    \<Tag
      ref={ref}
      className={cn('w-fit transition duration-200 ease-linear', className)}
      {...rest}
    \>
      {children}
    \</Tag\>
  )
}

// Create a hook to use the context
export const useMouseEnter = () =\> {
  const context = useContext(MouseEnterContext)
  if (context === undefined) {
    throw new Error('useMouseEnter must be used within a MouseEnterProvider')
  }
  return context
}

export const ContainerScroll = ({
  titleComponent,
  children, // Added children prop to allow custom card content
}: {
  titleComponent: string | React.ReactNode
  children: React.ReactNode // Added children prop
}) =\> {
  const containerRef = useRef\<any\>(null)
  const { scrollYProgress } = useScroll({
    target: containerRef,
  })
  const [isMobile, setIsMobile] = React.useState(false)

  React.useEffect(() =\> {
    const checkMobile = () =\> {
      setIsMobile(window.innerWidth \<= 768)
    }
    checkMobile()
    window.addEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
    return () =\> {
      window.removeEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
    }
  }, [])

  const scaleDimensions = () =\> {
    return isMobile ? [0.7, 0.9] : [1.05, 1]
  }

  const rotate = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], [20, 0])
  const scale = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], scaleDimensions())
  const translate = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], [0, -100])

  return (

      ref={containerRef}
    \>

        \<Card

      \</div\>
    \</div\>

// C3 - Ported from automationsaas context
'use client'
import React, { useRef } from 'react'
import { useScroll, useTransform, motion } from 'framer-motion'
import Image from 'next/image'

// Define the type for the asset being displayed
interface VisualAsset {
  src: string;
  alt: string;
  type: 'image' | 'gif';
}

export const ContainerScroll = ({
  titleComponent,
  visualAsset, // Accept the visual asset (image or GIF)
}: {
  titleComponent: string | React.ReactNode;
  visualAsset: VisualAsset;
}) =\> {
  const containerRef = useRef\<any\>(null)
  const { scrollYProgress } = useScroll({
    target: containerRef,
  })
  const [isMobile, setIsMobile] = React.useState(false)

  React.useEffect(() =\> {
    const checkMobile = () =\> {
      setIsMobile(window.innerWidth \<= 768)
    }
    checkMobile()
    window.addEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
    return () =\> {
      window.removeEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
    }
  }, [])

  const scaleDimensions = () =\> {
    return isMobile ? [0.7, 0.9] : [1.05, 1]
  }

  const rotate = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], [20, 0])
  const scale = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], scaleDimensions())
  const translate = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], [0, -100])

  return (
    \<div
      className="h-[80rem] flex items-center justify-center relative p-20"
      ref={containerRef}
    \>
      \<div
        className="py-40 w-full relative"
        style={{
          perspective: '1000px',
        }}
      \>
        \<Header
          translate={translate}
          titleComponent={titleComponent}
        /\>
        \<Card
          rotate={rotate}
          translate={translate}
          scale={scale}
          visualAsset={visualAsset} // Pass the asset to the Card
        /\>
      \</div\>
    \</div\>
  )
}

export const Header = ({ translate, titleComponent }: any) =\> {
  return (
    \<motion.div
      style={{
        translateY: translate,
      }}
      className="div max-w-5xl mx-auto text-center"
    \>
      {titleComponent}
    \</motion.div\>
  )
}

export const Card = ({
  rotate,
  scale,
  translate,
  visualAsset,
}: {
  rotate: any
  scale: any
  translate: any
  visualAsset: VisualAsset
}) =\> {
  return (
    \<motion.div
      style={{
        rotateX: rotate, // rotate in X-axis
        scale,
        // Customized shadow for aiascent.dev aesthetic
        boxShadow:
          '0 0 \#0000004d, 0 9px 20px \#0000004a, 0 37px 37px \#00000042, 0 84px 50px \#00000026, 0 149px 60px \#0000000a, 0 233px 65px \#00000003',
      }}
      // Increased height slightly to better accommodate screenshots/GIFs
      className="max-w-5xl -mt-12 mx-auto h-[35rem] md:h-[45rem] w-full p-6 bg-[\#222222] rounded-[30px] shadow-2xl"
    \>
      \<div className="bg-gray-100 h-full w-full rounded-2xl gap-4 overflow-hidden p-4 transition-all relative"\>
        {/\* Use Next.js Image component for optimization, even for GIFs \*/}
        \<Image
          src={visualAsset.src}

'use client'

import { cn } from '@/lib/utils'
import React, {
  createContext,
  useState,
  useContext,
  useRef,
  useEffect,
} from 'react'

const MouseEnterContext = createContext\<
  [boolean, React.Dispatch\<React.SetStateAction\<boolean\>\>] | undefined

> (undefined)

export const CardContainer = ({
  children,
  className,
  containerClassName,
}: {
  children?: React.ReactNode
  className?: string
  containerClassName?: string
}) =\> {
  const containerRef = useRef\<HTMLDivElement\>(null)
  const [isMouseEntered, setIsMouseEntered] = useState(false)

  const handleMouseMove = (e: React.MouseEvent\<HTMLDivElement\>) =\> {
    if (\!containerRef.current) return
    const { left, top, width, height } =
      containerRef.current.getBoundingClientRect()
// Reduced sensitivity for a more subtle effect
    const x = (e.clientX - left - width / 2) / 40
    const y = (e.clientY - top - height / 2) / 40
    containerRef.current.style.transform = `rotateY(${x}deg) rotateX(${y}deg)`
  }

  const handleMouseEnter = (e: React.MouseEvent\<HTMLDivElement\>) =\> {
    setIsMouseEntered(true)
    if (\!containerRef.current) return
  }

  const handleMouseLeave = (e: React.MouseEvent\<HTMLDivElement\>) =\> {
    if (\!containerRef.current) return
    setIsMouseEntered(false)
    containerRef.current.style.transform = `rotateY(0deg) rotateX(0deg)`
  }
  return (
    \<MouseEnterContext.Provider value={[isMouseEntered, setIsMouseEntered]}\>
      \<div
        className={cn('flex items-center justify-center', containerClassName)}
        style={{
          perspective: '1000px',
        }}
      \>
        \<div
          ref={containerRef}
          onMouseEnter={handleMouseEnter}
          onMouseMove={handleMouseMove}
          onMouseLeave={handleMouseLeave}
          className={cn(
            'flex items-center justify-center relative transition-all duration-200 ease-linear',
            className
          )}
          style={{
            transformStyle: 'preserve-3d',
          }}
        \>
          {children}
        \</div\>
      \</div\>
    \</MouseEnterContext.Provider\>
  )
}

export const CardBody = ({
  children,
  className,
}: {
  children: React.ReactNode
  className?: string
}) =\> {
  return (
    \<div
      className={cn(
        // Removed fixed h-96 w-96 for flexibility
        '[transform-style:preserve-3d]  [&\>\*]:[transform-style:preserve-3d]',
        className
      )}
    \>
      {children}
    \</div\>
  )
}

export const CardItem = ({
  as: Tag = 'div',
  children,
  className,
  translateX = 0,
  translateY = 0,
  translateZ = 0,
  rotateX = 0,
  rotateY = 0,
  rotateZ = 0,
  ...rest
}: {
  as?: React.ElementType
  children: React.ReactNode
  className?: string
  translateX?: number | string
  translateY?: number | string
  translateZ?: number | string
  rotateX?: number | string
  rotateY?: number | string
  rotateZ?: number | string
[key: string]: any; // Allow other props
}) =\> {
  const ref = useRef\<HTMLDivElement\>(null)
  const [isMouseEntered] = useMouseEnter()

  useEffect(() =\> {
    handleAnimations()
  }, [isMouseEntered])

  const handleAnimations = () =\> {
    if (\!ref.current) return
    if (isMouseEntered) {
      ref.current.style.transform = `translateX(${translateX}px) translateY(${translateY}px) translateZ(${translateZ}px) rotateX(${rotateX}deg) rotateY(${rotateY}deg) rotateZ(${rotateZ}deg)`
    } else {
      ref.current.style.transform = `translateX(0px) translateY(0px) translateZ(0px) rotateX(0deg) rotateY(0deg) rotateZ(0deg)`
    }
  }

  return (
    \<Tag
      ref={ref}
      className={cn('w-fit transition duration-200 ease-linear', className)}
      {...rest}
    \>
      {children}
    \</Tag\>
  )
}

// Create a hook to use the context
export const useMouseEnter = () =\> {
  const context = useContext(MouseEnterContext)
  if (context === undefined) {
    throw new Error('useMouseEnter must be used within a MouseEnterProvider')
  }
  return context
}

'use client'
import React, { useRef } from 'react'
import { useScroll, useTransform, motion } from 'framer-motion'
import Image from 'next/image'

// Define the type for the children prop, which will contain the visuals (images/gifs)
type ContainerScrollProps = {
titleComponent: string | React.ReactNode;
children: React.ReactNode; // Added children prop
};

export const ContainerScroll = ({
titleComponent,
children, // Destructure children
}: ContainerScrollProps) =\> {
const containerRef = useRef\<any\>(null)
const { scrollYProgress } = useScroll({
target: containerRef,
})
const [isMobile, setIsMobile] = React.useState(false)

React.useEffect(() =\> {
const checkMobile = () =\> {
setIsMobile(window.innerWidth \<= 768)
}
checkMobile()
window.addEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
return () =\> {
window.removeEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
}
}, [])

const scaleDimensions = () =\> {
return isMobile ? [0.7, 0.9] : [1.05, 1]
}

const rotate = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], [20, 0])
const scale = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], scaleDimensions())
const translate = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], [0, -100])

return (
\<div
className="h-[80rem] flex items-center justify-center relative p-20"
ref={containerRef}
\>
\<div
className="py-40 w-full relative"
style={{
perspective: '1000px',
}}
\>
\<Header
translate={translate}
titleComponent={titleComponent}
/\>

\<Card
rotate={rotate}
translate={translate}
scale={scale}
\>
{children}
\</Card\>
\</div\>
\</div\>
)
}

}

'use client'

import { cn } from '@/lib/utils'
// Removed unused import: import Image from 'next/image'
import React, {
  createContext,
  useState,
  useContext,
  useRef,
  useEffect,
} from 'react'

const MouseEnterContext = createContext\<
  [boolean, React.Dispatch\<React.SetStateAction\<boolean\>\>] | undefined

> (undefined)

export const CardContainer = ({
  children,
  className,
  containerClassName,
}: {
  children?: React.ReactNode
  className?: string
  containerClassName?: string
}) =\> {
  const containerRef = useRef\<HTMLDivElement\>(null)
  const [isMouseEntered, setIsMouseEntered] = useState(false)

  const handleMouseMove = (e: React.MouseEvent\<HTMLDivElement\>) =\> {
    if (\!containerRef.current) return
    const { left, top, width, height } =
      containerRef.current.getBoundingClientRect()
// Adjusted division factor from 25 to 40 for subtler effect
    const x = (e.clientX - left - width / 2) / 40
    const y = (e.clientY - top - height / 2) / 40
    containerRef.current.style.transform = `rotateY(${x}deg) rotateX(${y}deg)`
  }

  const handleMouseEnter = (e: React.MouseEvent\<HTMLDivElement\>) =\> {
    setIsMouseEntered(true)
    if (\!containerRef.current) return
  }

  const handleMouseLeave = (e: React.MouseEvent\<HTMLDivElement\>) =\> {
    if (\!containerRef.current) return
    setIsMouseEntered(false)
    containerRef.current.style.transform = `rotateY(0deg) rotateX(0deg)`
  }
  return (
    \<MouseEnterContext.Provider value={[isMouseEntered, setIsMouseEntered]}\>
      \<div
        className={cn('flex items-center justify-center', containerClassName)}
        style={{
          perspective: '1000px',
        }}
      \>
        \<div
          ref={containerRef}
          onMouseEnter={handleMouseEnter}
          onMouseMove={handleMouseMove}
          onMouseLeave={handleMouseLeave}
          className={cn(
            'flex items-center justify-center relative transition-all duration-200 ease-linear',
            className
          )}
          style={{
            transformStyle: 'preserve-3d',
          }}
        \>
          {children}
        \</div\>
      \</div\>
    \</MouseEnterContext.Provider\>
  )
}

export const CardBody = ({
  children,
  className,
}: {
  children: React.ReactNode
  className?: string
}) =\> {
  return (
// Removed fixed h-96 w-96 to allow flexible sizing
    \<div
      className={cn(
        '[transform-style:preserve-3d]  [&\>\*]:[transform-style:preserve-3d]',
        className
      )}
    \>
      {children}
    \</div\>
  )
}

export const CardItem = ({
  as: Tag = 'div',
  children,
  className,
  translateX = 0,
  translateY = 0,
  translateZ = 0,
  rotateX = 0,
  rotateY = 0,
  rotateZ = 0,
  ...rest
}: {
  as?: React.ElementType
  children: React.ReactNode
  className?: string
  translateX?: number | string
  translateY?: number | string
  translateZ?: number | string
  rotateX?: number | string
  rotateY?: number | string
  rotateZ?: number | string
}) =\> {
  const ref = useRef\<HTMLDivElement\>(null)
  const [isMouseEntered] = useMouseEnter()

  useEffect(() =\> {
    handleAnimations()
  }, [isMouseEntered])

  const handleAnimations = () =\> {
    if (\!ref.current) return
    if (isMouseEntered) {
      ref.current.style.transform = `translateX(${translateX}px) translateY(${translateY}px) translateZ(${translateZ}px) rotateX(${rotateX}deg) rotateY(${rotateY}deg) rotateZ(${rotateZ}deg)`
    } else {
      ref.current.style.transform = `translateX(0px) translateY(0px) translateZ(0px) rotateX(0deg) rotateY(0deg) rotateZ(0deg)`
    }
  }

  return (
    \<Tag
      ref={ref}
// Adjusted duration-200 to duration-300 for smoother animation
      className={cn('w-fit transition duration-300 ease-linear', className)}
      {...rest}
    \>
      {children}
    \</Tag\>
  )
}

// Create a hook to use the context
export const useMouseEnter = () =\> {
  const context = useContext(MouseEnterContext)
  if (context === undefined) {
    throw new Error('useMouseEnter must be used within a MouseEnterProvider')
  }
  return context
}

import { cn } from '@/lib/utils'
import Image from 'next/image'
import React, { useEffect, useState } from 'react'

export const InfiniteMovingCards = ({
  items,
  direction = 'left',
  speed = 'fast',
  pauseOnHover = true,
  className,
}: {
  items: {
// Updated type to support image href or text content
    content: string;
type: 'image' | 'text';
  }[]
  direction?: 'left' | 'right'
  speed?: 'fast' | 'normal' | 'slow'
  pauseOnHover?: boolean
  className?: string
}) =\> {
  const containerRef = React.useRef\<HTMLDivElement\>(null)
  const scrollerRef = React.useRef\<HTMLUListElement\>(null)

  useEffect(() =\> {
    addAnimation()
  }, [])
  
  const [start, setStart] = useState(false)
  function addAnimation() {
    if (containerRef.current && scrollerRef.current) {
      const scrollerContent = Array.from(scrollerRef.current.children)

      scrollerContent.forEach((item) =\> {
        const duplicatedItem = item.cloneNode(true)
        if (scrollerRef.current) {
          scrollerRef.current.appendChild(duplicatedItem)
        }
      })

      getDirection()
      getSpeed()
      setStart(true)
    }
  }
  const getDirection = () =\> {
    if (containerRef.current) {
      if (direction === 'left') {
        containerRef.current.style.setProperty(
          '--animation-direction',
          'forwards'
        )
      } else {
        containerRef.current.style.setProperty(
          '--animation-direction',
          'reverse'
        )
      }
    }
  }
  const getSpeed = () =\> {
    if (containerRef.current) {
      if (speed === 'fast') {
        containerRef.current.style.setProperty('--animation-duration', '20s')
      } else if (speed === 'normal') {
        containerRef.current.style.setProperty('--animation-duration', '40s')
      } else {
        containerRef.current.style.setProperty('--animation-duration', '80s')
      }
    }
  }

  return (
    \<div
      ref={containerRef}
      className={cn(
        'scroller relative z-20  max-w-7xl overflow-hidden  [mask-image:linear-gradient(to\_right,transparent,white\_20%,white\_80%,transparent)]',
        className
      )}
    \>
      \<ul
        ref={scrollerRef}
        className={cn(
          ' flex min-w-full shrink-0 gap-10 py-4 w-max flex-nowrap items-center',
          start && 'animate-scroll ',
          pauseOnHover && 'hover:[animation-play-state:paused]'
        )}
      \>
        {items.map((item, idx) =\> (
\<li key={idx} className="flex items-center"\>
{item.type === 'image' ? (
\<Image
width={170}
height={50} // Adjusted height for better aspect ratio
src={item.content}
alt={`scrolling-item-${idx}`}
className="relative rounded-2xl object-contain opacity-50"
/\>
) : (
\<span className="text-2xl font-semibold opacity-50 whitespace-nowrap"\>
{item.content}
\</span\>
)}
\</li\>
        ))}
      \</ul\>
    \</div\>
  )
}

You are an expert graphic designer specializing in branding and iconography for sophisticated developer tools. Your task is to generate visual assets for aiascent.dev, the official website for the Data Curation Environment (DCE) VS Code extension.

      * **Human-AI Collaboration:** Subtle motifs of connection, networks, or dual elements working together.

      * **Illustrations/Banners (PNG/WEBP):** Can be more detailed but must maintain the aesthetic. They should look professional and high-tech, avoiding cartoonish or overly playful styles.

'use client'
import React, { useRef } from 'react'
import { useScroll, useTransform, motion } from 'framer-motion'
import Image from 'next/image'

export const ContainerScroll = ({
  titleComponent,
  children,
}: {
  titleComponent: string | React.ReactNode
  children: React.ReactNode
}) =\> {
  const containerRef = useRef\<any\>(null)
  const { scrollYProgress } = useScroll({
    target: containerRef,
  })
  const [isMobile, setIsMobile] = React.useState(false)

  React.useEffect(() =\> {
    const checkMobile = () =\> {
      setIsMobile(window.innerWidth \<= 768)
    }
    checkMobile()
    window.addEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
    return () =\> {
      window.removeEventListener('resize', checkMobile)
    }
  }, [])

  const scaleDimensions = () =\> {
    return isMobile ? [0.7, 0.9] : [1.05, 1]
  }

  const rotate = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], [20, 0])
  const scale = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], scaleDimensions())
  const translate = useTransform(scrollYProgress, [0, 1], [0, -100])

  return (
    \<div
      className="h-[60rem] md:h-[80rem] flex items-center justify-center relative p-4 md:p-20"
      ref={containerRef}
    \>
      \<div
        className="py-10 md:py-40 w-full relative"
        style={{
          perspective: '1000px',
        }}
      \>
        \<Header
          translate={translate}
          titleComponent={titleComponent}
        /\>
        \<Card
          rotate={rotate}
          translate={translate}
          scale={scale}
        \>
          {children}
        \</Card\>
      \</div\>
    \</div\>
  )
}

export const Header = ({ translate, titleComponent }: any) =\> {
  return (
    \<motion.div
      style={{
        translateY: translate,
      }}
      className="div max-w-5xl mx-auto text-center"
    \>
      {titleComponent}
    \</motion.div\>
  )
}

export const Card = ({
  rotate,
  scale,
  children,
}: {
  rotate: any

  children: React.ReactNode
}) =\> {
  return (

// Note: This component is very large due to the extensive configuration object for tsparticles.

type ParticlesProps = {
  id?: string
  className?: string
  background?: string
  particleSize?: number
  minSize?: number
  maxSize?: number
  speed?: number
  particleColor?: string
  particleDensity?: number

      // console.log(container)
